awd_titl_txt: Advancing Theory and Application in Perceptual and Adaptive Learning to Improve Community College Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
Developmental mathematics remains a critical obstacle to college readiness, involving large majorities of community college students and disproportionately impacting groups of students who are underrepresented in STEM - minority, low-income, and first generation college students. This project aims to improve our understanding of important instructional principles emanating from cognitive science that are related to success in community college mathematics.  The studies in this project aim both to advance our understanding of learning and to apply learning innovations to known challenges in authentic learning settings, thus testing and extending the generalizability of laboratory findings to consequential mathematics learning with diverse learners. The team will focus on two areas of research in the cognitive science of learning that have that have important implications for learning complex domains like mathematics and science. The first is perceptual learning, which accelerates learners' abilities to quickly and accurately recognize key structures, patterns, and relationships. The second area is the development of adaptive learning algorithms that utilize real-time performance data in conjunction with principles of learning to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of learning by tailoring the learning process to each individual student. This project is designed both to advance the scientific understanding of perceptual and adaptive learning and to assess their potential to improve learning in community college mathematics.

Several sets of experiments will investigate basic scientific questions regarding 1) whether and how there may be a unified account of the benefits of spacing of learning events that applies across different forms of learning; 2) how intermixing passive and interactive events may improve adaptive learning; and 3) how adaptive methods may be used to enhance the role and benefits of comparisons in perceptual learning. Basic principles will be established through research in controlled laboratory studies. The project will then extend these findings by conducting applied tests of these principles to optimize the effectiveness, efficiency, and durability of learning, and to maintain motivation, with community college students enrolled in remedial mathematics courses. 

This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. The program supports the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest intervention and innovations to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning and participation.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on scientific studies of emerging concepts of learning and their applications to learning technology. We build on recent progress showing the importance of perceptual learning -- domain-specific improvements in perception that guide learning in complex domains. We combine these advances in learning with principles of adaptive learning to understand their operation and to optimize their applications into advanced learning technology. Applied to scientific and mathematical domains, perceptual learning accelerates learners' abilities to recognize and discriminate key structures and relations. This process, which is not well addressed by conventional instructional methods, is facilitated by interactive learning episodes that are further enhanced by adaptive learning algorithms that utilize real-time performance data and principles of learning and memory to guide each individual learner to effective, efficient, and comprehensive mastery of learning content. In this project, we investigated the combination of perceptual and adaptive learning, as well as features of each, in laboratory experiments and in community college mathematics settings. The methodologies and technologies created and refined through this project have allowed us to examine key questions about how learning works and how directly addressing pattern recognition through perceptual learning addresses aspects of learning that students often find difficult. By including different types of learning material and learning contexts within a single project--in particular, including complex real-world learning as well as more controlled laboratory settings--we have been able to probe and refine our understanding of learning mechanisms and how they might best be applied. 

Our laboratory studies sought to advance scientific understanding of the basic principles in these areas of cognition and learning, with the aim of using the results to design successful learning technology interventions. Experiments addressed basic scientific questions regarding how to order and space learning items during learning; the benefits of passive and active learning modes and their combination; the role of comparisons in facilitating learning; and the impacts of varying the strictness of mastery criteria. One notable finding from laboratory studies is that initial passive learning followed by active learning yields better outcomes than either passive or active learning alone for both perceptual and factual learning. Another advance is the discovery that using individual confusions to adaptively trigger comparisons in learning can markedly improve perceptual learning.

As a complement to laboratory studies, we also conducted a series of studies with community college students, who used web-based Perceptual and Adaptive Learning Modules (PALMs) that applied principles and findings from our studies to consequential content in their gateway algebra courses. While not all findings from the laboratory studies generalized directly to the content, participants, and settings of the community college studies, the overall approach has consistently yielded successful learning outcomes. In addition to research findings from studies, an important outcome of this project is development of a suite of five web-based PALMs focusing on important topics in college algebra.

The PALMs were particularly designed to help math learners develop more expert accuracy and fluency in perceiving important structures and relations as they are expressed in graphs and equations using standard notational conventions. Many math students focus on learning to perform calculations and procedures but struggle because they have difficulty seeing mathematical representations as intuitively meaningful or seeing connections among similar content as it appears in different formats. An example of this approach to learning can be seen in the accompanying figure.

The parameters and settings in this suite of PALMs have been optimized using research data from multiple groups of community college students across four cohorts. For example, results from studies of mastery criteria indicate that long term retention is not significantly better for material learned to stricter criteria of accuracy and fluency and so is less efficient. These findings have been incorporated into final versions of the PALMs to increase completion rates for more students while maintaining learning gains.

The PALMs can be flexibly combined with other instructional resources, and they are designed to adapt dynamically to students with different levels of preparation. They have been tested and used successfully as part of normal course curricula, yielding robust reliable learning gains in both in-person and online asynchronous instructional formats.

 As the trend toward online learning has accelerated dramatically, it is more important than ever to ensure that new curricular resources are deeply rooted in basic scientific understanding of human learning processes. It is also important to realize that traditional approaches to instruction address the declarative and procedural aspects of learning, but also crucial are learning methods, such as PALMs, that advance students' pattern recognition and intuitive abilities. The outcomes from this project provide a foundation of learning principles and innovations in learning technologies that can be applied to other domains to make learning more adaptive for students with differing levels of prior knowledge and more efficient and reliable overall.
